        Consolidated Content:
The US Open has been chronologically the last of the four Grand Slam tournaments of the tennis season since 1987. The Grand Slam tournaments consist of the Australian Open, the French Open, Wimbledon, and the US Open, each played over a two-week period. The US Open is played on hard courts in late August and early September. The Grand Slam Cup was a separate tournament held annually from 1990 through 1999, inviting the best-performing players in the year's Grand Slam events to compete. The ITF's definition of the Grand Slam has evolved over time, initially broadening to include any four consecutive major victories, and later specifying that players must hold all four titles in one calendar year to achieve the "Grand Slam."

Additionally, the evolution of the ITF's definition of the Grand Slam, which initially broadened to include any four consecutive major victories and later specified that players must hold all four titles in one calendar year to achieve the "Grand Slam," further solidifies the US Open's position as the last Grand Slam tournament of the year.

Answer:
The last Grand Slam tennis tournament played in a calendar year is the US Open.
